comments.commentBody:
I am a graduate student who studies cognition and driving in several different populations. We're about to start a study now looking at driving in teens and young adults using a driving simulator -- and we're definitely not the only lab doing this type of research. If you're a parent interested in getting this type of experience for your teen, I'd recommend doing a google search and looking for research opportunities.

Several commenters have added that we should really be looking at impulsivity or "reckless drivers" even though this study clearly shows that those behaviors only contribute to a small subset of crashes. However, I think they do have a point -- the authors say that they were only looking at the most proximal pre-crash event. A more comprehensive view of the causal chain leading up to the pre-crash event may find that poor decision making (of which reckless driving is only a small subset) occurred in many of these crashes. Studying crashes can only go so far -- research using new technologies, such as simulators and video-equipped smart cars, can tell us more about the events leading up to an accident, and is the next step in this line of research.

To commenter #23, T in PDX, there certainly have been studies that have looked at novice drivers of different ages. Here are two citations if you're interested:
Laapotti, S., Keskinen, E., Hatakka, M., & Katila, A. (2001). Novice drivers' accidents and violations - a failure on higher or lower hierarchical levels of driving behaviour. Accident Analysis and Prevention, 33(6), 759-769.
Mayhew, D. R., Simpson, H. M., & Pak, A. (2003). Changes in collision rates among novice drivers during the first months of driving. Accident Analysis and Prevention, 35(5), 683-691.
The best gift for any parent is the gift of time. It seems mothers and fathers do not get enough support so important things like exercise and good nutrition are sacrificed.

"Automakers, hoping to stand out from the herd..."
-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-.-

If they need to make such an effort to stand out from the herd, that can only mean a second-rate product.

I have no idea why I have such VERY fond memories of my Saab 96. 3-cylinder, 2-stroke, smelly, cold, loud, did I mention smelly? Engine so small and lightweight that I could (and did) lower it into place with one hand while lining up bolts with the other. Primitive front-wheel drive with death-wish "freewheel" option (turn off all engine-braking, whether in-gear or out).

And always, hanging over you, like a perfect moral reputation utterly ruined by just ONE date with a sheep, is the thought of filling the petrol tank without putting the oil in first.

Oh sure, there was the fact that the entire car flew, weighed little, and absolutely nothing would stay it from the swift completion of its appointed rounds. And there was also the SOUND, the WHIngdingydingydingyding... that would cause entire columns of schoolboys' heads to swivel in unison, imagining Erik Carlsson might be coming down the high street sideways.

Richard Thompson perhaps put it best (just possibly while singing about something else entirely): "If I could just taste all of her wildness now, well I wouldn't want her any other way."
We need more fotos !

To all the naysayers,  these two men are doing what to many people say cant be done, they are actually making something in OUR country. I will be watching the progress closley and be in line when they come to market.   What would attempt if you knew you would not fail?

I put the equations from Gary 17 and Charles 29 into grapher and got four hyperbolas. As Gary said they don't all intersect at any one point. The point 2.66, 2.66, 5.30 is pretty close to hitting them all.

Gary #21,

I think your intuition is correct in that the surfaces created by possible box lengths don't intersect in real space. You can go from exactly 37 to exactly 83 but you have to then change the dimensions a bit to go from exactly 83 to exactly 157.

jrkenti #20,

I agree with you. Good point. Amazing, in fact, how we always round off when measuring things like length but never round when measuring countable things like dogs and cats. Perhaps this volume problem could be rephrased using creatures instead of inches.
Deb – That is such a great clip.  Somehow, I have the feeling that it refers to more than TERSE.
I cannot believe that before this rule if one's baggage was lost the baggage fee was not refunded.
Don't we have anything better to do than re-regulate the airline industry?  Even Jimmy Carter knew that it was a bad idea.
Bravo!  Now if only they would let me take a bottle of sun lotion in my carry on...
I guess the airlines havent kicked in with their re-election campaign donations yet.

Next they should repeal or sharply reduce the walk-through-the-airport taxes ("Passenger Facility Charges") that add as much as $50 to an airline ticket.  And, of course, stop the TSA patdowns and X-rays.

End the corporate welfare and reinstate sensible tax codes and our financial problems will go away.

Sadly, that isn't possible, since the government no longer works for the people. Instead, we'll see more political Kabuki until the next crisis hits and the choice of enacting good legislation will be lost in the face of disaster.

Milton Friedman would be proud.

Count me in as another Yankee who despises everything about Texas and Texans. Texas gets about $1.50 from the Federal government for every $1.00 it pays in taxes. We need to reverse that ratio for 20 or 30 years, until Texas pays back every cent it's sponged off the rest of us.

Mickeyrad#2...Ok, you're a Scrooge.
Wonder if you are screaming as loudly at the GOP's record so far. They were elected to create jobs and instead have taken 4 recesses and the only bills they have been promoted are Not about Jobs at all, instead are social/religious issues.

When are we going to form a Gang of Six that's going to work on getting the unemployed back to work?  Seems they've been become victims to the deficit reduction hysteria that's taken over the public forum.  The only thing we hear now are different players bragging about how much sacrifice their particular austerity program is going to inflict upon the American people, the more the better.  The truth of the matter is that the unemployed and the under employed don't need any more pain.

OK, Mickey, you're a Scrooge. Trust me: there's nothing in the Bible about Easter eggs. In the US, this is a secular tradition and it's a great opportunity to get kids to focus on healthy eating and exercise. (Instead of the usual Easter candy-induced hyperactivity and crankiness.) You have a problem with that? As the saying goes, all politics is local. It turns out all jobs are local, too. The banks have plenty of money, the stock market is doing well, the rich got to keep more of their money - where's that trickle down we've been hearing about since Ronnie Raygun's day? Where's that jobs legislation Bonehead was going to focus on like a laser? All we've seen so far is the GOP job-killing budget threats.....I mean proposals. Kids don't care about budgets. They want to chase eggs and play. As Scrooge said, "Are there no workhouses?" Well, no - but maybe you'd like the kids to be sent back into the mines and factories? Get a grip. Have some malted milk balls. Roll an egg.
Now is the very moment of Spring in Washington. Maybe we can just celebrate the natural processes of renewal.

Obama is clearly the best Republican candidate. Romney is almost identical on the issues, but has a shady past with cutting American jobs.

Who will the Democrats nominate? Someone who cares about jobs, about working people? Russ Feingold? Howard Dean?

Obama - only a hair's difference from Palin or Trump or any of Obama's fellow clowns competing for the Republican nomination [excluding the reputable Romney, of course]. Maybe it's time to go Green and vote for the Green Party.
The Democrats should look for whose support is decisive in Mr. Obama winning a second term.
Yeah, Texas is just horrible.  So horrible, in fact, that lately you can't swing a dead cat without hitting a transplanted Northeasterner.
Too bad this discussion with distinguished members of both parties wasn't discussed over luncheon.  Then, they could have had a food fight.
Can someone please get around to releasing our financial aid that's being held hostage- kinda in limbo here y'all.
